description:
I ran into bug 903878 due to a missing 'veth' module.  The issue rendered itself as libvirt failing to start an instance.   So, this should be easy to reproduce simply by removing that module and deleting the veth.ko file.

After that failure:

$ euca-describe-instances
RESERVATION     r-62nu1r0g      2       default
INSTANCE        i-00000003      ami-00000001    server-3        server-3        running mykey   1               m1.tiny 2011-12-13T20:46:08Z    nova
RESERVATION     r-1x0c4bdo      2       default
INSTANCE        i-00000001      ami-00000001    server-1        server-1        error   mykey   1               m1.tiny 2011-12-13T18:59:15Z    nova
RESERVATION     r-wm84ckwd      2       default
INSTANCE        i-00000002      ami-00000001    server-2        server-2        error   mykey   1               m1.tiny 2011-12-13T19:02:01Z    nova

there were 2instances in 'error' state, and /proc/mounts contained
/dev/nbd15 /opt/stack/nova/instances/instance-00000001/rootfs ext3 rw,relatime,errors=continue,barrier=1,data=ordered 0 0
/dev/nbd14 /opt/stack/nova/instances/instance-00000002/rootfs ext3 rw,relatime,errors=continue,barrier=1,data=ordered 0 0
/dev/nbd13 /opt/stack/nova/instances/instance-00000003/rootfs ext3 rw,relatime,errors=continue,barrier=1,data=ordered 0 0

I did a 'euca-terminate-instances i-00000001' and the relevant mount actually was cleaned up, so that was good.
However,  well (minutes) after the terminate, the instance still showed up in both 'nova list' and 'euca-describe-instances' as 'error'. 
However, I wonder 2 things:
 a.) should the failed libvirt errorhave resulted in cleaning up the mount itself
 b.) is 'nova delete' or 'euca-terminate' supposed to remove an instance that is in 'error' state?

Related bugs:
  * bug 903878: libvirt-bin broken for lxc in precise
title: libvirt lxc failure path does not clean up mounts
